displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it? Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but um the injection is just liquid medication that gets injected and it forces your testosterone level to go down. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The testicles produce testosterone as a normal function. PAT Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have less testosterone in your body and so that helps get rid or any or suppress or get rid of any cancer cells that are remaining. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Do they die or are they just inhibited? Doctor: Yeah they like ninety nine percent die then maybe not one hundred precent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So that’s with the injection. Then there’s a little cylinder, a little flexible cylinder about this long – Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: - that can be implanted under the skin.

Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws. Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Doctor: Well, it’s, it’s, kind of altogether. You know? So it’s the lumbar, it’s the lower lumbar is where your- Patient: Radiation treatment was.

Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see. Patient: That was what that Radium two point three was - Doctor: Well it did it for quite a while. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Patient: And it worked. I could feel it working. You know I think that was great. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that -

Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm.

Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh. Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. Hhh (chuckles) Family Member: So, until Doctor: So, I’ll, I’ll start that. You’re gonna need to sign a permission and all that with T_. Healthcare Professional: Yep.

Family Member: Now he also if he says I’m through with this, I don’t want it no more. Doctor: Then we stop. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Absolutely. Healthcare Professional: This is totally voluntary. You don’t have to do the study medication. I mean the study, like she said, this medication he can get off study. Doctor: Right. Healthcare Professional: And if he feels like he’s having side effects or just doesn’t want to do it anymore or participate, just let me know. Doctor: Same thing. I would manage the side effects whether you’re on the study or not. Family Member: Right. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Whether you’re on the study or not, you have a problem at one a.m. on a Saturday, you still page me.

Family Member: But she said is so vitally important - Doctor: - If she needs to call me – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - I would rather you over call than you know totally ignore - – Family Member: Ignore it. Doctor: - and then you get really sick by the time you show up in here. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was. Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card.

Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right. Doctor: Depending on what side. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put a needle through – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Doc They take samples out – Patient: Okay!

Healthcare Professional: Sorry, excuse me. Doctor: So um…just want to go over what's going on and sort of your scan results. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me ask first what your questions are. And then I can give you some thoughts. Patient: My question would be what are your thoughts about it? I mean, when you and I talked, we were kind of like, well, let's take the scans and see what comes up. We didn't necessarily think anything would because it's so small the numbers that we're reading right now. Doctor: Yeah, I still believe that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So either specialty as long as they have a focus on spine surgery that’s what we want, really. You know, because- Family Member: Okay. Okay. Yeah. Patient: He had me get an x-ray, the neurosurgeon, because he wanted to make sure I didn’t have Pancoast tumor? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. No. Don’t worry. No. No. No. Family Member: Alright. He said, oh, it’s, you know, it’s some weird- Doctor: Oh, my, oh, my, God. That is a scary thing to say and leave it hanging like that. Patient: I think he was trying to get rid of me. I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. Yeah. That’s not something we would ignore or taken lightly, either. Patient: Okay. So then you’re going to give me an appointment for three months here? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If there’s another increase by fifty percent of then Patient: Okay. What’s the timeframe for the observation? Are we talking like a six month period of observations or what you’re saying that if I for whatever was to receive the observation does that one day receive the observation that would just remain until I hit the forty-two which could be like it could be a year? Doctor: So that’s, so that’s where the Patient: Okay. Doctor: You raise a very good question. Then if you go with the observation group and the PSA would still rise Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: and twelve months later your PSA is stabilizes Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Um, hum. And that is Doctor: In your case, if I would have to guess with your PSA track record –
